Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). So, if we're looking at dihybrid crosses or other combinations, how do the parents' genotypes look? The options given are A to J, but let me list them: A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb

The key here is figuring out the genotype of the parents that would produce such a ratio when crossed. Since the ratio is ¾ black to ¼ white, this implies that in each offspring, there must be at least one dominant allele (B) present because the recessive condition (bb) leads to white. If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats. So any parent who is bb would cause all their offspring to have white coats. However, since the parents aren't all producing white, they can't both be bb. Therefore, at least one parent must be heterozygous (Bb), giving some chance of passing on the dominant allele. But wait, let me consider the possible parent combinations: Option D is bb × bb. Looking further, let's check other options. Option A is Bb × Bb. Both parents are heterozygous. Using a Punnett square, the possible offspring would be BB (25%), Bb (50%), and bb (25%). But according to the problem, ¾ are black, which includes BB and Bb, and ¼ are white (only bb). That fits perfectly. So option A also works. Option C is bb × Bb.
